If we are to have increased expenditure on equipment and new bases, which I support most strongly, at the same time we have to make sure that sufficient moneys are available within the defence vote to ensure that defence housing is equal to the task required of it. The housing has to be of sufficient standard to encourage defence personnel to go into these northern areas and give service there. The shortage has increased by some 1,600 houses in the past five years, due largely to a reduction of some 1,200 in the stock level over the same period. The 1,200 reduction has been due to an accelerated rate of disposal of unsuitable stock in recent years.

At any one time over the last decade 7,000 to 10,000 married Service personnel have accommodated themselves outside defence arrangements, that is, neither occupying defence housing nor being paid allowances for their accommodation costs. At present it is estimated that some 6,700 Service personnel own their own homes. About half of these are thought to be occupying homes in areas which coincide with their postings. So that is having the effect of easing the demand.

In 1978-79, as I said, $22m was spent to complete some 478 houses; in 1979-80, $7m was spent to complete 116 houses; in 1980-81, $8m was expended for the completion of 90 houses; in 1981-82, $16m was spent to complete some 246 houses; and in 1982-83, $21m was spent to complete 443 houses. As I understand it, it was indicated during the hearings of the Estimates committees some two weeks ago that some $30m to $40m a year will be spent on defence housing. So, in 1983-84 the projected figure is $34m to be spent on the completion of 500 houses. Of course, these new houses are not replacing those houses that are no longer used because of old age. Current defence housing planning is aimed at using the funds available as effectively and equitably as possible throughout Australia by providing additional housing where there is a shortfall and where suitable rental accommodation is not readily available, replacing as quickly as possible the worst of the 12,000 below standard houses that I have mentioned, and improving older houses which, because of limited funds, cannot be replaced for at least 15 years.

I note in a report that I have been studying that there is a five-year forward program. The current planning for the five-year period 1984-85 to 1988-89 provides for the following: Some 1,270 additional houses at an estimated cost of $94m; 1,640 replacement houses at an estimated cost of $118m; and improvements to some 2,700 houses at an estimated cost of $36m. This all sounds well and good , but when one takes note of the original stock of houses available and the number of houses that have to be removed from that stock because of age, one realises that a very big problem exists in relation to defence housing in Australia.

I come closer to home-as a senator representing the Northern Territory-and refer to the situation in Darwin. Darwin has been a very important Royal Australian Air Force base over the years. It has been given more prominence over the period of its existence. Of course, quite a large number of RAAF personnel are stationed in Darwin. Honourable senators will remember that Darwin was struck by a very serious cyclone, Cyclone Tracy, at Christmas 1974. A most difficult situation has developed there. Very strict building codes, based on a cyclone code, have been introduced to apply to houses built for the civilian community, if I can put it that way, in the Darwin area. However, in the centre of Darwin where the RAAF is stationed, there are something like 250 houses that are not built to cyclone standards. I believe this to be a very serious omission . If in future a cyclone of the intensity of Tracy should strike-of course, that will happen because there is a serious and intense cyclone in the area about once every 30 years-the RAAF personnel, their wives and children will be in the dangerous situation of living in these houses that are not built to cyclone standards.

It will be remembered that when Cyclone Tracy struck most of the damage was caused and people were injured and killed-60-odd people were killed in that cyclone-by flying debris. If a cyclone of the intensity of Cyclone Kathy which struck Borroloola a few weeks ago-it had an intensity similar to that of Cyclone Tracy-were to strike in the Darwin area, extreme damage would be caused to Darwin once again, and such damage would occur because so many houses in the Darwin RAAF base have not been constructed to cyclone standards. Just as debris flew over such a wide area of Darwin during Cyclone Tracy in 1974, the same thing could happen in Darwin again, but this time the debris would come from the RAAF base in Darwin. Apart from the people living on that base being at risk, the civilian population living in the vicinity of the RAAF base would be equally at risk.

Repairs and maintenance work on those houses at the base is overdue. Such repair and maintenance work has been curtailed because of the uncertainty of the future of the RAAF base in Darwin. As I said, now that firm plans are being made for the development of a major RAAF base at Tindal, it should be possible to set in train a management plan to upgrade for interim use the older RAAF houses at Darwin. However, it has been said that no funds are available to carry out repairs and maintenance work on these houses because of the possibility that moneys will be required to establish the Tindal base. It has been said that no money will be available to carry out repairs and maintenance on these houses in Darwin for the next five to 10 years. That is an incredible situation. I come back to what I was saying in the first place, that a balance is required in the development of our defence system in the north of Australia.

It is worth noting a description I have read of the situation at the Darwin RAAF base: Of the 300 houses on that base, 247 are in various stages of disrepair because of the lack of funds. Of these 247 houses, 36 were built during the period 1939-45, during the Second World War. All are seriously deficient in scales and standards. Most are not weatherproof and have significant electrical, water supply, drainage and sewerage problems. It has been reported to me that at times serious problems are encountered with the sewerage system on the base in Darwin. However, no money is available to carry out repairs and maintenance work on that system. I remind the authorities at this stage that they could have a very serious outbreak of disease on their hands, and I refer to typhoid. Most of the balance of these houses were built between the end of World War II and the late 1950s. These, too, are showing signs of the lack of repair and maintenance work and are classified as being below the minimum standard for the lowest rank. The number of members and dependants affected in varying degrees by poor housing standards is estimated at 950.

This gives some indication of the immensity of the problem. Those people are seriously disadvantaged by continual electrical or plumbing problems, and they have no privacy in their houses. In some 150 houses bedrooms are only partially partitioned; that is, the partition does not go right to the floor or to the ceiling. Honourable senators can imagine the lack of privacy that that creates. According to the local manager of defence services in the area, the problem is simply a lack of funds to carry out repairs and maintenance in the period 1983- 84.

While recognising the problems that the Government has with the huge capital expenditure required for the purchase of new equipment, FA18 fighters and the construction of new bases-all of which are most necessary for the defence of the north-at the same time I ask it to make available the funds necessary to upgrade Defence Force houses in the north. Many thousands of Defence Force houses in Australia need repair and maintenance; they are not up to standard. But I point out that in the north houses are prone to cyclone damage, as happened during Cyclone Tracy in 1974, and efforts must be made-and made soon-to remedy the situation. One cannot expect RAAF personnel and others in the Defence Force to move from the south to northern bases if houses there are not up to standard. I say emphatically that the housing standard in the north is not what it should be . There are difficulties in encouraging people to move voluntarily to those bases. Morale is not good in the RAAF base at Darwin or, for that matter, at other bases that suffer from the same problems. So I request the appropriate authorities to look into this matter and I do so for two reasons.

The cyclone period for Darwin for this wet season has passed but the next wet will come along in November-December 1984. Perhaps there will be another cyclone . A cyclone of the intensity of Cyclone Kathy, which devastated Borroloola some weeks ago, makes one realise what could happen in Darwin in the wet at the end of this year. One could expect extreme damage to houses on RAAF bases and in the vicinity of Darwin. There could be more deaths and injuries. I leave those matters for the authorities to consider and look forward to balanced development of the various defence bases in the north.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the acquisition of some five million acres of land in the Cobar Shire by the Army. I guess that that will involve the expenditure of a not inconsiderable sum of money by the Army this coming financial year. It is rather unusual that a Queensland senator should raise a matter concerning the people of New South Wales. However, I was approached by a group who called themselves the Fighters for Survival. They are women from the Cobar area of New South Wales concerned that good land in that area is to be acquired by the Army. In a quite lengthy letter sent to me after I had been interviewed by them the women pointed out that, because of Western Lands Commission price controls, the money landholders will receive will prevent them forever from buying other property. Apparently the sale price of land in the Western Division is about $6 an acre compared with a buying price of $50 an acre in the central region of New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: The ladies who came to see me said that widows and retired persons in the Cobar area have a real problem because, as the Army proposes to acquire land in that area, they cannot sell at reasonable prices. In fact, I suppose they would be unable to sell at all because of the threat that the Army will take over their land. They may have to wait for the Army to resume it. That is not a prospect that anyone living in the Cobar district is happy about. I suppose that the Army must acquire land somewhere for its operations but the people of Cobar feel that it should conduct them on land that is not so good and not so well developed.

On the five million acres there are to be four impact areas which will be uninhabited. All year round only 20 men will be there. The area will be used for manoeuvres only two or three times a year, perhaps amounting to 120 days out of 365. It seems to me to be a waste of good land. I understand from the women who came to see me that the Cobar area is a picture at present. At different times I have thought that Cobar is in a rather dry part of New South Wales. However, the women assure me that they have had good rains and it is very nice at the moment. But everyone is upset about the proposed acquisition by the Army. The women feel there will be quite a backlash when the Army takes over their land; there will certainly be an economic downturn for small businesses in the town due to the fact that rural landholders will not occupy those five million acres. Also, there will be the loss of small schools and the bus runs to those schools, as well as the uncertainty of the future of young people on the land.

Some young people like life on the land. My son is one. I sometimes wonder, when considering the problems faced in developing a new property and living long distances from townships, just why young men and women would want to continue to live on the land. I suppose if they were not willing to set up homes in the outback, the economy of rural Australia would smartly fade away. I read an interesting editorial in the Australian recently. It related these rather sad facts about the concerns of farmers:

Farmers are in reality slowly going bankrupt-while costs are rising by 10 per cent a year, real prices are declining. But what incentive is there for farmers with an average income of $11,500, earned from average capital of $450,000, when the national average income is about $13,500?
Thus the national average income is some $2,000 more than the farm income, despite a lot of hard work. The editorial continued:
As it is, thousands of Australia's 170,000 wheat, beef, sugar, pig, poultry and dairy farmers face the real prospect of being forced off the land in the next five years.

That is a rather sad state of affairs. Perhaps a few people in Australia will be hungry if that does happen. The Government ought to take cognisance of those facts. Those on the land realise that costs are increasing while prices of commodities seem to be decreasing. I remember that when the Labor Government came to office it promised lower petrol prices. That did not happen. The man on the land and everyone else paid increased prices for their petrol although, admittedly, one can get a 2c rebate on diesel fuel.

However, I know that every so often I have to submit a claim for the excess amount that we pay on diesel fuel. I am sure that there must be many farmers or farmers' wives who are very annoyed from time to time about the fact that they have to pay more for diesel fuel than they used to and have to submit a claim to get a refund.

We all know that life can be hard for the man on the land if it does not rain at the right time. This is the case if one lives in the far outback. Plenty of places in Queensland are suffering from a lack of air services. This can be a real problem. It is very difficult to get television reception in many places in the far outback. So life out there is not as lovely as people sometimes seem to think it is.

It seems to me that the requisition by the Army of 5 million acres of the Cobar area will create an unemployment problem. There are enough problems in regard to unemployment in Australia now without creating any more, as will happen in the Cobar area when the acquisition takes place. I think that the Government needs to tackle many problems for rural Australia-not only the rural area of Cobar in New South Wales but also rural Queensland, the State for which I am glad to be a senator. I think the Government has to tackle the problems of high inflation, steep interest rates, high government charges and, in some cases, generous wages .

The women representatives of Fighters for Survival instanced the case of Mrs McInerney, a shearing contractor in the Cobar area. I have always said that women should be allowed to do what they want to if they have the ability. Apparently she must have the ability to do this work. I am not too sure whether she does the shearing herself. Maybe she is just a good organiser. Maybe she organises the men. Having watched sheep being shorn, I do not think I would like to be a shearer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did we need the sex discrimination legislation?

—That was not explained to me. Apparently she has been able to organise this gang to carry out its shearing work. She is very worried that her shearing team will lose work in the Cobar area if this land is acquired . Apparently, at present she has 20 weeks work. As I see it, all of these problems will result from this acquisition of land by the Army in this part of New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: Another point the Fighters for Survival raised with me was the fact that a pipeline runs through the defined area for approximately 200 kilometres. I could not imagine that the Army would not know about a fact like that. These people wish that the Army would look somewhere else for the land that it needs for training purposes. We all know that the Army needs areas to train its troops. Actually, I also feel that Australia badly needs cadet forces. Young men should be given the opportunity to train at their schools. Many Queensland schools which have been in touch with me are very concerned that the cadet corps is gradually being phased out of schools.

I should point out that the affected landholders, comprising 140 families, are very concerned about the proposed acquisition of land in the Cobar area. I do not know whether the Army has considered other areas where the land is not so good. However, the women of Cobar-the Fighters for Survival-say: 'No, this is it '. I wanted to take this opportunity during the debate on the appropriation legislation to raise this matter which is causing so many headaches. I presume also that the money made available through the appropriations will be used in this coming year gradually to take over the land. I certainly feel sorry for the people in this area. I ask the Army and the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) to look at the possibility of acquiring for Army manoeuvres land which may not be quite so valuable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have the opportunity in debating the legislation before the Senate tonight to give a general summation of where we are at politically in Australia and to make an assessment of the Government's record up to this time.

—Senator Teague, you can do that within the constraints of the appropriations package, but I will not provide you with an opportunity simply to use the appropriations package to go outside the bounds of the Bills before the Senate.

—We have the opportunity to range widely in a general way over those matters of government spending which are the Appropriation Bills, whether it be in the areas of social welfare, education or unemployment. We have the opportunity to speak about the impact of the Government's decisions upon families and the scope of the Government's spending as a result of Budget decisions.

SPEECH.PARA: It is now more than 14 months since the Australian Labor Party Government was elected. In the initial months following Mr Hawke's success and the change of government the Australian people were prepared to give a fair go to the new Government. One of the strategies of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) which has been very successful-at least this was the case last year-has been to try to keep the honeymoon atmosphere going, to try to get the Australian public to hold its breath and give this Government a chance. Of course, there was a setback in that hardly any of the promises that had been made during the election campaign were going to be honoured by the new Government. A certain amount of toleration had to be won from the Australian people as they saw so many of the promises that had excited them and influenced them to vote for the new Hawke Government would not be fulfilled. Despite the lack of fulfilment of the promises, the Prime Minister and other members of the Government were out to keep the honeymoon going, to keep up the popularity of the Government.

During that time the Prime Minister sought to be associated with every major sporting event that was held. During 1983 Australia had some marvellous sporting successes. As part of the Government's aim of keeping up the honeymoon period, keeping up the concept of a fair go and keeping the Australian public on side, this association with sporting victories has proved to be a successful strategy by the Prime Minister. Meanwhile members of the public have been holding their breath, wondering when they will be given an opportunity to make a judgment on the Government's decisions. I am afraid that the Government has not been making very many decisions. I think it was realised even as early as last year that an election probably would be called early for political purposes. It was realised that an attempt would be made to get the present Government re-elected as early as November or December 1984. So I believe that at a very early stage-this is quite evident when we look at the Government's record over the last 14 months- there was a clear decision not to make any hard decisions, certainly not to make any decisions that would lead to the Government being unpopular.

The commitments reflected in the Budget which really showed a socialist Government building foundations for the future were hidden and covered up. Those actions which contrast strongly with the former Fraser Government's restraint and approach to achieving small government, deregulation and less intrusion into people's lives were hidden and covered up where this pattern was broken by the Hawke Government. The public hardly realised that despite a 2 per cent real increase in the size of government spending in seven Fraser Government Budgets- that is over seven years-there has already been a 7.2 per cent real increase in the first Budget of the Hawke Government.

Often the Australian public hears Liberal politicians saying that the Liberal Party's approach is to achieve small government but the socialist government will achieve big government which means big bureaucracy, big taxes and big spending. Here we have evidence of this straight away. There has been a 7.2 per cent increase in real terms in the first Budget of the Hawke Government compared with only a 2 per cent increase in real terms over the whole seven years of the Fraser Government. Another comparison can be made about the size of the bureaucracy, the size of Public Service. Over the first two years of the Hawke Labor Government, average staff levels in the Federal Public Service were budgeted to increase by almost 10 per cent. That is about 10 times as much as the total rise in the size of the Public Service over the whole seven years of the Fraser Government. There has been a 10 per cent increase in just two years under the Hawke Government compared with a one per cent increase in the seven years of the Fraser Government.

However, these stark comparisons between the record of the socialist Government and the record of the Liberal-National Party coalition Government have been hushed up and hidden so that the foundations being built by the Hawke Government for a socialist future are not being fully realised by the Australian public. Let us consider one other comparison. It relates to the promise that was given during the election campaign to overcome unemployment in Australia. I am sad to say that over the last 14 months, there has been hardly any change at all in the unemployment figures in Australia. At the time of the last election, in March 1983, 10 per cent of Australians were unemployed. That is an Australian Bureau of Statistics figure on unemployment in Australia. Tragically, 10 per cent of Australians were unemployed. That unemployment came about as a result of the drought and the international recession which reflected very badly upon the former Government in the eyes of many voters. They were the principal reasons for the Australian public's trying to find hope in the brave promises of the Hawke Government at election time which allowed it to form a Government in March 1983. What has happened since then? Just 12 months later the unemployment rate was 9.3 per cent. That was a marginal improvement and reflected the ending of the drought and the enormous turnaround in the international economy. Happily, that has been reflected in some small improvement in unemployment in that time.

Where will we be in March 1985? What is the unemployment figure now? It is back to 10 per cent. I fear that by March 1985, two years after the election of the Hawke Government, the figure will be considerably more than 10 per cent. That will not be an accident. It will be a direct outcome of the approach to wages that the Hawke Government has determined in compact with the trade union movement. Because there has not been sufficient wage restraint wages have gone beyond the level which Australia can afford; so companies have not experienced profits and have not been able to take on new employment. Also, because the high wages are beyond the amount that Australia can genuinely afford, we are not competing internationally and so Australia has suffered. We have dropped behind like-structured economies in the world, in the other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. We are now performing considerably worse than the other Western economies. That fact has been covered up and hidden so that the apparent honeymoon, the apparent fair-go period, of the new Government might be eked out a little longer.

Another matter that has been covered up is the way the Labor tax decisions have hit the ordinary families of Australia. The great majority of families are now paying, in real terms, higher taxes as a result of decisions taken by the Hawke Labor Government. It has been calculated that the average Australian family, that is, a family consisting of a husband, wife and two children, with average weekly earnings, is $17 a week worse off as a result of the Hawke Labor Government's election even at this time, 14 months after the election. The average family will have $900 a year less to spend as a result of the tax decisions already made by the Hawke Government. This is partly explained by the increased taxes taken by way of the Medicare levy and partly by the increases in wages in money terms because of inflation but with no corresponding adjustments being made to the tax thresholds of 30c in the dollar to 46c in the dollar. As a result of the Labor Government's decisions about taxes the average family is now $900 a year worse off or $17 a week worse off.

Whether it is the Labor Government's big spending-the 7.2 per cent increase in real terms in the first Budget; the big bureaucracy-the 10 per cent increase in the number of Federal public servants in the first two years of the Labor Government; the non-answer but, rather, aggravation that has been brought to the unemployment statistics of Australia; or the tax hike that is hitting Australian families, the Government has tried to cover up so that the honeymoon period of the Hawke Government, begun in 1983, might be eked out just a little longer.

There is other evidence which is very clear in the structure of these Bills that are before us and in the decisions about spending and the related policies which demonstrate again the decision of the Hawke Government to become popular at all costs. I believe that, not only in this Parliament, but also in Australia at large we should be very wary of a Prime Minister who wants to be popular at all costs and we should be very wary of a government that wants to be popular at all costs. Some tough decisions need to be made whether they relate to industrial relations, wages policy or to limiting government spending. Those tough decisions need to be made for the good of Australia. However, if a government is so convinced that it must remain popular, it will be reluctant to make tough decisions and see its support wither away.

Let us look at three or four more examples of this constant goal of popularity. Let us consider the assets test. It was announced last August in the Budget. The assets test was to be loaded upon the pensioners of Australia. Two million Australians are directly involved. These two million Australians were all to have their assets valued to see what amount the Hawke Government could take from them in terms of their fortnightly pensions. When the overwhelming response was against such an assets test-it was taken up by us as clearly and coherently as we could in opposition in the Parliament-what happened? The formula for popularity was being broken. Hawke stepped in on 22 February and made an announcement, without even telling his Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) or his colleagues in the Government. He just stepped in and said: 'The whole assets test is too unpopular. It has to be suspended and we will try to achieve this policy by referring it to a community panel of experts'.

The Assets Test Review Panel, chaired by Professor Gruen, was set up from that day to investigate the assets test and, hopefully in the mind of the Hawke Government, to come back with a fairly tough policy, a set of recommendations, that would still put the burden upon pensioners that was intended in the Budget decision but which could be pinned upon some apparently neutral and expert community committee. It was an attempt just to push a difficult decision on to some other independent body and to use that as a device then to explain to the Australian public why these two million pensioners would all receive some valuation form, some prying document, that would ask about their assets and upon which it would be decided whether their pensions would be decreased as a result. The Prime Minister knew that all of these difficult things would come but he would be able to say that the Government could not do otherwise because it was relying on the clear advice of a community committee of experts.

The same was done with the Alice Springs to Darwin railway. People in the Northern Territory in particular will recall that there was a very clear promise by the Labor Party in the last election campaign to build that railway line. It said that it would build the railway line from Alice Springs to Darwin. The Liberal and National parties were already committed to do that. When it was seen that the cost might be $600m and when it was seen that there was only one seat in the Northern Territory that the Labor Party had won only narrowly, the Hawke Government made a decision that the $600m could be forgone. But how would the Government explain it to all the people who were expecting the promise to be fulfilled? It said: 'Let us refer it to a committee', and it was referred to the Hill Independent Economic Inquiry into Transport Services to the Northern Territory, which investigated the possibility of an Alice to Darwin railway. Surprise, surprise, despite all the submissions that came in to say how much it would benefit Australia, the Hill inquiry came down with a report that it was not sufficiently viable and that the Prime Minister had better not go ahead with it. Here was something that the Prime Minister could put his feet on. He could stand up and say to the Australian public that it could not go ahead. He had a golden excuse for reneging on that promise.

The people of the Northern Territory are not fooled. As a Liberal senator from South Australia, I know that the South Australian people are not fooled. The South Australian people knew that the railway would bring great benefit to the State and to the people of the Northern Territory. The South Australian Chamber of Commerce was unanimous about the importance of it and about its viability. I am not just saying this. Detailed careful analysis was given to all parliamentarians and to the Government in South Australia. Mr Bannon, the Labor Premier, believed that it was not only an important project for South Australia and the Northern Territory, but also a viable project. So, as is well known, he sought to change the mind of the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister said to him, as he said to the public: 'I had an expert committee, and Mr Hill tells me that it is not viable, and of course we should not be spending money in this way'.

We have seen exactly the same procedure followed with the assets test but I warn the Government that it will not be able on Friday of this week just to make some decision to place a great burden upon the pensioners of Australia and get away with blaming it on some independent expert committee, even if it is chaired by Professor Gruen. The decisions made within a government are made by the Ministers of that government, by the Prime Minister, by the Cabinet, by the politicians, on the basis of their being elected by the people of Australia. They cannot run away from the responsibility to make decisions which must be worn at the coming election. So, with regard to the assets test, we see again an example of something appearing to be unpopular with the people in a serious way and so the Government puts it off and sends it to a committee. It does not want to disturb the waters. It says: 'Let us keep the honeymoon going. Let us eke out a few more months. We will have our early election, perhaps by Christmas, and see if then we can get on with a clear run of three or four years to implement the socialist program'.

Another example of this was the enormous fight that went on over the Medicare arrangements. In the few months leading up to 1 February, the Australian public became more and more concerned at the anomalies, costs and difficulties associated with the introduction of Medicare. One of the problems concerned the doctors themselves. The doctors were so put off by the Government's implementation of Medicare and were so distanced by not being consulted that they found themselves almost trapped into contracts that were unilaterally decided by the Government without proper input by or consultation with the medical profession. Medicare was to demand of doctors that they participate on grounds of contracts written autocratically by the Government. As is well known, there was notice of a strike, an unprecedented action for Australia. The medical profession proposed to take industrial action to oppose these unilaterally determined contracts being laid upon them. Of course, the public began to be used by the Government as part of the weapon in the fight against the doctors. The threat was made that ordinary members of the public would not receive a Medicare benefit if the medical practitioners had not signed the contracts that were offensive to them. There was such dismay felt then by the public and the medical profession that eventually the level of unpopularity got so high that the Prime Minister said to his Minister for Health, Dr Blewett: 'You must give in. You must cave in to the doctors. Let us pass it off to another committee. We will give it to the Penington inquiry and so save ourselves. We can eke out a few more months of popularity and maybe the Penington inquiry will report even after the Parliament has got up in June. It will all get lost in the Budget decisions of August and we may be able to keep our popularity long enough for an early election in November or December'.

It is the same formula that we saw in the earlier examples. So whether it is the assets test in social security or the doctors' contracts and Medicare arrangements, we see the same formula-an obsession with popularity, an inability to take tough decisions and an appeal to a so-called expert independent community committee as an excuse to make decisions that are unpopular. The same is happening in the field of education, particularly with regard to government and non-government schools.

I note that there is not one Government senator in the chamber. There are Liberal and National Party senators but not one Minister. Of course Senator Harradine, from Tasmania, is here but there is not one Labor Minister or back bencher; they have arranged meetings in the corridors and in their rooms to try to be popular. 'How can we save ourselves from all these difficult decisions before us?', they are saying. They are not here to hear the wisdom of the Opposition; they are not here to be a part of this debate on these important Appropriation Bills. I think it is the first time, at least in recent weeks-it has never happened in my time here-that a Government member has not been present .

TALK.START.PARA: —It has happened to me since this Government has been in.

—Senator Martin says it has happened to her but it is still the case that there is not one Government senator in the chamber. Yet another example of this mania for popularity relates to government and non-government schools. Such were the decisions last year of the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, Senator Ryan, and of the Hawke Government that they alienated the 25 per cent of Australian families who have children in independent schools. Not only was there the 41 school hit list and the complete blocking of capital grants for any new independent schools but also the percentage link which had been the stable foundation for years was abolished and the principle of a recurrent grant for every child was put at risk by the decisions of the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: During the Budget session of Parliament last year, the Opposition took up the cry of the Australian public and brought the abandonment of these principles very much to the fore in debate in the Parliament. As a result, there were meetings of hundreds of thousands about the country and education became an enormous issue. Of course it was an issue which created some unpopularity for Senator Susan Ryan, the Minister, as well as for the Hawke Government. The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, stepped in; he saw that the level of unpopularity had risen to such an extent that it was putting in jeopardy the continuing honeymoon and tolerance amongst Australians to give the Government a fair go. He said: 'I must rein in my Minister and make sure that she is quiet; we must have an inquiry'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Teague, you are speaking on the appropriation package and I cannot find your current remarks relating to the Appropriation Bills. I ask you to bring your debate back to the Bills.

—I will bring them back very carefully, by saying that such were the unpopular decisions in the education field, in the area of direct financial spending by the Government, that the Prime Minister had to step in, call for a Commonwealth Schools Commission inquiry and ask the experts to give some advice. The experts have now given that advice, which reinforces everything that the Opposition has been saying; that is, to bring about a percentage link, to bring back a basic grant for all students and to make sure that there is fair support for every child in Australia. So we have seen the same pattern emerge. The present Government is seeking to be popular at the expense of being fair dinkum with the Australian people.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to Appropriation Bill (No. 3 ) 1983-84 insofar as it relates to the Additional Estimates concerning the Departments of Social Security, Trade, Industry and Commerce, Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Administrative Services and the Treasury. In so doing I will be dealing with questions of unemployment and the unemployment benefit, family support and the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations-not the matter we recently dealt with but prohibited imports insofar as they have been produced by slave labour-and I will raise questions concerning the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we would all agree that one of the greatest issues confronting Australia today is unemployment. The figure in the Estimates and Additional Estimates for the unemployment benefit is too high-I am not saying that the unemployment benefit rate is too high; I am saying that the amount set aside for payment by way of unemployment benefit is too high-and the amount set aside for family support schemes, including the family allowance, is too low. They are somewhat interlinked. One of the problems that we have faced recently in respect of unemployment is that we have been side-tracked by certain things. I do not discount the fact that the unemployment debate last month was centred on the stint of a member of the other chamber on the dole for a week. Whilst no doubt that stint was well intentioned, in my view his experiment was detrimental to the unemployed and also to those parliamentarians, both State and Federal, with long-standing concern for the unemployment problem. In fact, the surrounding publicity diverted attention from the causes of unemployment and therefore from its solution.

The unemployment debate too often ignores the fact there are in Australia more people in or seeking paid work than there are jobs available at the same time as new job opportunities are being slashed by the haphazard introduction of automation and technological change. Literally hundreds of thousands of people now in the paid work force would, if given a true freedom of choice, leave it to pursue the important socially creative work which they desire to carry out. This bears very directly on the request that has been made in the Additional Estimates in respect of unemployment. Everyone concerned with the unemployment problem should be now pressing the Government to make sure that the August Budget provides the economic basis required for this freedom of choice. The major priorities are justice for the family, particularly the one income family, and sensible retirement measures enabling those who wish to opt for early retirement to do so without a dramatic loss in living standards.

For many years I have been warning that unless we realise that the unemployment problem has a social as well as an economic aspect we will not get near solving it. For too long the unemployment question has been treated like a political football. On the one side all the blame has been put on the unions and wage rates and so forth and on the other side it has been put on the Government or on the previous Government's policies. But we must realise that the problem has a social as well as an economic aspect. I was very pleased to see that the Prime Minister of Australia (Mr Hawke), in his John Curtin Memorial lecture in Perth in December 1983, as quoted by the Women's Action Alliance in its submission sent to all members of parliament, said in respect of unemployment:

The plain fact is that no Government in Australia will now, or in the foreseeable future, solve the problem of unemployment solely through the available methods of increasing the supply of jobs. At least equal attention must be paid to the question of reducing the demand for jobs by helping to provide socially constructive alternatives.

That statement does not wear well with the statement that was made by the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) and reported yesterday in the Canberra Times. She indicated that it was possible to have 100 per cent employment. She is right, of course, but only if we accept that the problem has a social as well as an economic aspect. As the Prime Minister said:

The plain fact is that no Government in Australia will now, or in the foreseeable future, solve the problem of unemployment solely through the available methods of increasing the supply of jobs. At least equal attention must be paid to the question of reducing the demand for jobs by helping to provide socially constructive alternatives.

What more socially constructive alternative work is there in Australia than the nurturing, care and development of one's own children? The fact is that so many mothers with dependent children are forced by economic pressures to keep down another outside job. It is unfair to them, to the young unemployed and to the whole of the community for this situation to be allowed to continue.

Nothing that I say ought to be latched onto by anybody as questioning the right of any person to enter the paid work force, be they married, unmarried, male, female or whatever else. But the fact remains that we are faced with dramatic consequences if we do not understand the true structure of the unemployment with which we are faced today. We all know, some of us from the experiences of our families, of the unemployment facing young people. The unemployment rate for young people in Australia is 25.9 per cent for girls aged 15 to 19 years seeking full time paid work and 24.3 per cent for youths. In Canberra, as I understand it, in a report this morning the figure was put at 30 per cent. In my State-I stand to be corrected in relation to the April figures because I do not have them at my fingertips-according to the last figure that I saw the unemployment rate for girls 15 to 19 years seeking full time work was 32.3 per cent. Those figures are devastating and they cry out for correction.

All types of affirmative action will not create another job. I believe there is discrimination in certain areas and that has to be rectified, but let us face the fact that affirmative action and even the sex discrimination legislation will not help that situation. Let us clear that up very carefully. In fact, it might slightly exacerbate it because of the fact that an employer cannot discriminate against a person because of marital status. I do not want to argue that aspect, but a fact of life is that affirmative action and the sex discrimination legislation may exacerbate the problem for young girls 15 to 19 years of age. The point I am making is that there are so many people in the paid work force who, given a true freedom of choice, would opt out of the paid work force and leave jobs available for the young unemployed. I have indicated that such people include mothers with dependent children who are forced by economic pressures to keep down another job and the large number of persons who desire to retire early. Given the opportunity, without an attendant dramatic loss in the standard of living, these people may choose to retire. Of course, I understand those questions are being addressed by the Minister who is in the chamber at present, the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes). I only hope that something can be done about that aspect.

Mothers are forced into the paid work force not only because of the cost of housing and of keeping the second mortgage going. The cost of living is rising despite the negative increase in the consumer price index. In addition to those factors, the tax system at present disadvantages one income families. Those with children are being denied their rights to indexation of family allowances. The Institute of Family Studies on page 2 of its annual report supports what I have said. It states:

There is no doubt that many families are finding the task of providing for their members' needs more and more difficult . . . The tax treatment of families has favoured those without children and has particularly disadvantaged large families.
A number of other very interesting comments are made in the report which I will not go into. The report makes an important point about the family. It says:

. . . the family acts as an economic unit in influencing production, it affects the transfer of wealth or disadvantage from generation to generation, it is an agent of socialisation, it is the main unit of economic consumption, and it is the primary context for development of interpersonal relationships, a context that can be destructive as well as enabling and supportive.

A very good document has been submitted to the Government by the Women's Action Alliance. I think it would be recognised that that document was prepared after a great deal of thought and is based on factual evidence. It is not a ranting or raving document. Nobody can say that this group is an extreme group. It has put the case quite clearly. It has detailed the reasons for married female work force participation. It has attempted to pull together some of the references on measuring unpaid work. The group talked about the spouse rebate. While I am on that subject I must say that it worries me that there has been no real impact at the Economic Planning Advisory Council level in support of the family. The only document that was publicly available from EPAC relating to the family was a document which suggested the abolition of the spouse rebate. I know that the Government would not agree with that. Not only would it be unjust but also it would torpedo the accord. Everybody knows that that is a scatterbrained idea.

The document dealt with the family allowance. This matter, as I said before, has not received the attention that it should have. I have here a document which was prepared by the Commonwealth Parliamentary Library's statistics group setting out the family allowance for the first child to the fifth child and the amount of loss that has been incurred over the period that the family allowance has not been indexed, and the loss has been quite substantial. TALK.START.PARA: —Because of the time factor and because I would possibly be offending the Standing Orders if I ranged too far, I should like very briefly to summarise what I have said. SPEECH.PARA: I wish to refer to the subject of immigration and ethnic affairs. Much has been said on this question. I am pleased that at least the heat of the debate is diminishing. I believe the Prime Minister has stated in a most humanitarian way that the Government intends to pursue that policy. I note that there has been a substantial drop in the number of Asian immigrants this year compared with last year. I am concerned about that.
